Scope and form:
Project group work related to Process design and intensification.
Some short lectures may be delivered based on the students background and needs to execute on the group project work.
6 week intensive course.
Duration of Course: [The course is not following DTUs normal Schedule]
Type of assessment:
Oral examination and reports
Submission of final reports. Oral examination as project presentation.
Academic prerequisites: 28750 , Knowledge of process design and mathematical modeling is beneficial
General course objectives:
General course objectives
To run a group project related to process design and intensification in the biomanufacturing industry. The project will include literature survey, basic and more advanced mathematical models.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Introduction process intensification principles
Examples of intensified processes in biomanufacturing
Executing on identifying process hot spots
Implementing intensification concepts to achieve more sustainable process design
Validation and comparison of designs from an economic and environmental point of view
Critical assessment of societal and symbiotic implications of the design decisions
Perform a project in a group of students
Disseminate project results in a technical report
Content: The course will include visit to an industrial site with thorough introduction to process design and hot spot identification, lessons with lectures and exercises related to process design, process intensification and sustainable process development, literature survey of process intensification principles with examples from implemented technologies across biomanufacturing, identifying an existing industrial process hot-spot and addressing the hot spot through improvement by process intensification.
Course literature: Lecture notes and additional book chapter/journal publications
